creator: AkankshaSrivastava
title: Crystal Ball: See Into Your Future!
materials_required: 3D printer (for the crystal ball and covers)
description: This project details how to build a crystal ball that uses an Arduino, LCD monitor, and a button to display a random fortune each time the button is pressed. The crystal ball is designed to guide you through life's challenges by offering advice with each press of the button.
steps: Connect the button to the Arduino by connecting the ground (GND) pin on the Arduino to the GND of the button. Then connect the 5v pin on the Arduino to the other pin of the button. Finally, connect pin 3 on the Arduino to the other pin of the button.

Connect the LCD to the Arduino, placing the LCD and potentiometer on the breadboard and connecting them with jumper wires. Connect D6 on the LCD to pin 6 on the Arduino, and connect the positive rail on the breadboard to 3.3v instead of 5v.

Code the Arduino using the Arduino app. Import the LiquidCrystal library and create an array of about 50 short fortunes. Write an "if else" statement that allows the Arduino to give one fortune each time the button is pressed.

Measure the space occupied by the breadboard and Arduino to design covers for them using Autodesk Inventor. Create a button cover and a larger cover for the LCD, breadboard, and Arduino, ensuring precise dimensions for a proper fit. Make sure you measure the LCD with the breadboard exactly.
Design or purchase a crystal ball, optionally designing it in Autodesk Inventor and 3D printing it. Aim for a diameter of 5" for the ball and 3.5" for the stand, extruded 2" down.

Before attaching the parts, confirm that the code works by pressing the button to display a fortune on the LCD. Place the LCD cover over the LCD and Arduino, and place the button cover over the button. Run the jumper wires through the hole on the side of the LCD cover and the button cover, then reconnect them to the button. Hot glue the covers to a firm board and super glue the crystal ball to the top of the LCD cover. Connect the Arduino to a power source to start predicting your future.
